references: Brennan, T. C. and Holycross, A. T. 2009. A field guide to amphibians and reptiles in Arizona. Arizona Game and Fish Department. Phoenix, Arizona.
Jones, L.C.C. and Lovich, R.E. (eds.). 2009. Lizards of the American Southwest: A Photographic Field Guide. Rio Nuevo Publishers, Tucson, Arizon. 567pp.
NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
Bartlett, R. D., and P. P. Bartlett. 1999. A field guide to Texas reptiles & amphibians. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.
Dixon, J. R. 2000. Amphibians and reptiles of Texas. Second edition. Texas A & M University Press, College Station.
Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.
habitat_description: This species occupies a vast area of Arizona, most of southern New Mexico, and northern Texas. In Mexico, it occupies Zacatecas, San Luis Potosi, and Western Tamaulipas (Bartlett and Bartlett 1999, Degenhardt et al. 1996, Dixon 2000, Stebbins 2003). In Arizona, this species is commonly found above the flats of bajadas, hillsides, and mountain slopes of Upland desertscrub, semidesert grassland, interior chaparral, and Great Basin conifer woodland (Brennan and Holycross 2009). This species is an inhabitant of the Chihuahuan Desert, extends into shortgrass prairie, east to the Edwards Plateau,  parts of the northern Sonoran Desert, and also the southeastern edge of the Mojave Desert. Found in the western plains of south Texas, Texas panhandle, southern New Mexico, Rio Grande and Pecos River drainages, Sonoran uplands, below the White Mountains and Mogollon Rim; to the Big Sandy River drainage and the Hualapai and Cerbat mountains (Jones and Lovich 2009).
